#  System and foreign language interfaces
<hr />
<p><a href="" id="Operating-system-access"></a> <a href="" id="Operating-system-access-1"></a></p>
<h3 id="operating-system-access" class="section">7.1 Operating system access</h3>
<p>Access to the operating system shell is via the R function <code class="calibre7">system</code>. <a href="" id="index-system"></a> The details will differ by platform (see the on-line help), and about all that can safely be assumed is that the first argument will be a string <code class="calibre7">command</code> that will be passed for execution (not necessarily by a shell) and the second argument will be <code class="calibre7">internal</code> which if true will collect the output of the command into an R character vector.</p>
<p>The functions <code class="calibre7">system.time</code> <a href="" id="index-system_002etime"></a> and <code class="calibre7">proc.time</code> <a href="" id="index-proc_002etime"></a> are available for timing (although the information available may be limited on non-Unix-like platforms).</p>
<p>Information from the operating system <a href="" id="index-environment-17"></a> environment can be accessed and manipulated with</p>
<blockquote>
<code class="calibre7">Sys.getenv</code>
OS environment variables <a href="" id="index-Sys_002egetenv"></a>
<code class="calibre7">Sys.putenv</code> <a href="" id="index-Sys_002eputenv"></a>
<code class="calibre7">Sys.getlocale</code>
System locale <a href="" id="index-Sys_002egetlocale"></a>
<code class="calibre7">Sys.putlocale</code> <a href="" id="index-Sys_002eputlocale"></a>
<code class="calibre7">Sys.localeconv</code> <a href="" id="index-Sys_002elocaleconv"></a>
<code class="calibre7">Sys.time</code>
Current time <a href="" id="index-Sys_002etime"></a>
<code class="calibre7">Sys.timezone</code>
Time zone <a href="" id="index-Sys_002etimezone"></a>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="" id="Foreign-language-interfaces"></a> <a href="" id="Foreign-language-interfaces-1"></a></p>
<h3 id="foreign-language-interfaces" class="section">7.2 Foreign language interfaces</h3>
<p><a href="" id="index-_002eC"></a> <a href="" id="index-_002eFortran"></a> <a href="" id="index-_002eCall"></a> <a href="" id="index-_002eExternal"></a></p>
<p>See <a href="http://colinfay.me/writing-r-extensions/system-and-foreign-language-interfaces.html">System and foreign language interfaces</a> in Writing R Extensions for the details of adding functionality to R via compiled code.</p>
<p>Functions <code class="calibre7">.C</code> and <code class="calibre7">.Fortran</code> provide a standard interface to compiled code that has been linked into R, either at build time or via <code class="calibre7">dyn.load</code>. They are primarily intended for compiled <strong>C</strong> and FORTRAN code respectively, but the <code class="calibre7">.C</code> function can be used with other languages which can generate C interfaces, for example C++.</p>
<p>Functions <code class="calibre7">.Call</code> and <code class="calibre7">.External</code> provide interfaces which allow compiled code (primarily compiled <strong>C</strong> code) to manipulate R objects.</p>
<hr />
<p><a href="" id="g_t_002eInternal-and-_002ePrimitive"></a> <a href="" id="g_t_002eInternal-and-_002ePrimitive-1"></a></p>
<h3 id="internal-and-.primitive" class="section">7.3 .Internal and .Primitive</h3>
<p><a href="" id="index-_002eInternal-1"></a> <a href="" id="index-_002ePrimitive-1"></a></p>
<p>The <code class="calibre7">.Internal</code> and <code class="calibre7">.Primitive</code> interfaces are used to call <strong>C</strong> code compiled into R at build time. See <a href="./R-ints.html#g_t_002eInternal-vs-_002ePrimitive">.Internal vs .Primitive</a> in R Internals.</p>
